dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a lab mouse. Our world is a cage; the laboratory beyond the wire mesh has the sprawling limitlessness of a universe with dark endless voids and immense technological instruments gleaming with celestial light. We can hear a WOMAN'S VOICE though we can't understand what she is saying. There are several other lab mice in our cage and as the voice gets closer there is sense of mounting apprehension We fight the other mice, pushing into the far corner. Suddenly the world beyond the mesh is eclipsed by the WOMAN. If we were not a mouse, we might think she was beautiful. She opens the cage and a panic erupts. There is nowhere to hide as her hand reaches in and TAKES HOLD of us. The cage seems to fall away as she LIFTS us. We can barely hear her voice over the blood pounding in our ears. She TURNS us OVER and we see an enormous hypodermic needl that she uses to inject us with a sapphire-blue fluid. We are then placed in a small air-tight tank. There is a small Plexiglas window and several tiny holes. After a moment we hear the HISS of VALVES OPENING. A milky fluid suddenly floods the chamber and we begin to feel nauseous, our VISION BLURRING and DISTORTING. As quickly as the fluid filled the tank it now drains. The god-like hand again LIFTS us from the tank but something is wrong because -- We SLIP THROUGH her fingers.  The GROUND RUSHES UP at us but when we hit -- We BOUNCE. And BOUNCE. FLIP FLOPPING, the bounces coming quicker and quicker, LOWER and LOWER until we are RACING ACROSS the floor. Free! We see the woman in her white lab coat screaming at her assistant as they try to corral us. We DODGE, ZIPPING ACROSS the floor, looking for a way out when we see, set in the tile floor, a drain. The WORLD SWIRLS WITH us as we DASH TOWARDS it, the dark holes widening as we DIVE at them, PLUNGING HEADLONG INTO

dialogues.speaker: BLACKNESS --
dialogues.text: TUMBLING DOWN the rabbit hole. After a long silent moment, we hear a MAN SNEEZE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DARKNESS BECOMES a curtain that is yanked open as the same MAN steps out talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hi, Susan... no. Hi, Susie... We realize he has just stepped out of a photo booth. We do not see his face, MOVING WITH him, staying waist high as he waits for the photo strip.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Howdee, Susan... no... Hello there, Doctor Bright. No no no. Hello, Susan... A smoldering octave lower.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Susan... The green light flashes and the strip of black and white pictures drops into the gate. We DESCEND PAST each picture of the man's face, framed tightly as if each was a panel in a comic book. Each face seems like someone who has a secret or who is trying to look very smart. Except for the last one which looks like he was about to sneeze.  The man grabs the strip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An upscale neighborhood: Brownstones and coffee houses. Dr. Susan Bright (WOMAN) steps out of her door. She is the scientist that we saw in the OPENING SCENE. She is in a hurry, juggling a briefcase, an armful of books, a cup of coffee and her keys as she heads for her car. She is bent to the car door as we GLIDE UP BEHIND her.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Susan. The voice hits her like the Hymlich maneuver.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What god would that be? She turns around and we see the man; Daniel "Eel" O'Brien Black leather activist. We cannot tell if he is dangerous or just trying to look dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Daniel...

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN, (MAN)
dialogues.text: What? No kiss? Not even for old times sake? She forces a smile and gives him a hug. His hand slips into her lab coat pocket and then away.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: When did you...?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Been out for six months now.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Really? What have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You know, this and that. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Still chasing litterbugs? His grin has an edge to it.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Somebody has to.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Same old Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh no. Not by a long shot. I may look like the old Daniel O'Brien, but on the inside, nothing is the same.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. See, Susie, a man doesn't do the hard time and just pick up where he left off. Ohno. The big house does things to a man.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The big house?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: The big house.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, Daniel. It wasn't Ryker's Island. It was work camp for white collar criminals.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: A cage by any other name would still smell like sweaty ugly men. Sounds like the same O'Brien to her.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You know, I've been following your work at Argon Labs. Her smile disappears.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about you a lot all these years, locked up in my cell. I'd tear through every issue of the Midwest Science Journal looking for your latest findings, watching as you slowly worked your polymerization experiments up through single celled organisms to  that holiest of holies, the fruit fly. Exciting stuff. I got to tell you, it really kept me going.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I guess I should be flattered.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I remember you said, nanotechnology was going to change the world.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It already is.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I've read they're using it to repair cancer cells.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: And for cleaning up oil spills.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Right. You predicted it. He moves closer, eyes smoldering. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Do you ever wonder what happened to us, Susie?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It was a long time ago, Daniel. We were young, different people, heading in different directions. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well, it was good to see you, Daniel, but I have to be going.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Sure. Can I ask you one more thing? You haven't published anything in a while. How come? She shrugs, getting into her car.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Nothing really worthwhile.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: That's what I thought.  She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Be seeing you. She watches him turn and walk away in the rearview mirror She GUNS her car's ENGINE and the SOUND ROLLS INTO -- The ROAR of SMOKESTACKS, gaseous flames burning into boot black clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An industrial wasteland; towering smokestacks and warehouses of corrugated steel, factories and chemical plants built around a small lake that shimmers with an oily iridescent sheen while its shores churn a frothy green bile. One of the more distinct buildings in this skyline of black steel and blue-gas flame, is Argon Laboratories. It is a heavily secured compound. There are two oblong buildings: one is the main lab building, the other is a chemical warehouse. Where the two buildings are connected, a third structure rises on a steel framed skeleton like a water tower. This is Argon Tower and at the top of the two story private manor, built beside a helicopter pad, is a twinkling glass conservatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of gleaming, red-patent leather stiletto-heeled SHOES CLICK delicately across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Icarus? We FOLLOW the high heels THROUGH the office until we see the base of a statue and the name chiseled into stone; "Icarus Argon". We RISE UP the nine-heads-high, heroically proportioned statue and see Icarus Argon as he once was; a single halogen high-lights the massive David-like physique. She crosses the sprawl of the office and everywhere are mementos marking the milestones of Argon's life. His face beams on framed magazine covers; People's "Sexiest Man Alive," and Time's "Man of the Year". A 1989 Mr. Universe trophy is almost lost in the thicket of awards. The Woman calls to the wheelchair-bound figure slouching  behind a black, obelisk-like desk.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Icarus, I thought I would find you here. She is Mrs. Poppy Argon, a stunning woman of cosmetic perfection and a body that might have been surgically cut from a comic book. She designs her own dresses made from Argon rubber or PVC usually red to match her collection of high heeled shoes and boots.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY, (WOMAN)
dialogues.text: You never came to bed. He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Have you been here all night? She moves around him and we get our first look at the new Icarus Argon.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: How are you feeling today? He is an unwrapped mummy; brown flesh drapes over stringy cords of muscle like a wet paper bag. His eyes, hard white marbles lined with red cracks, coldly stare up at her.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON, (MAN)
dialogues.text: I feel like I felt yesterday. She feels his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Like rotting meat.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: You're not rotting meat. He lifts his arm.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Oh no? Smell this.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Icarus, please, if you want me to give you a bath just say so.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: No. I'm getting used to it. She opens a manila folder, setting several sheets of pape  on a tray in front of him. He snatches the

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Fine. Now I need your signature on this today. pen from her and begins signing everything she lays in front of him. Poppy sighs. She gathers her She pats him on

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: What about Dr. Bright?

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: She's working as fast as she can, Icarus. It will be ready soon.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: It's ready now, I know it is.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: She says it's not.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: She's lying. She lost the first one on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: She did not. The mouse ran down the drain.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: She let it escape because she wants me to die.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Don't be a child, Icarus. She is just another scientist and like all scientists, she doesn't care about anything outside the world of the laboratory. papers back into the folder.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Right now she is still concerned about the unstable molecular waste generated by the first experiment. I am sure that when she solves that problem she will be ready for the second test. the head.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Now you be a good boy today and take  your medicine and Poppy will make you forget about everything tonight. She blows him a kiss, wiggling her long red-nailed fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan Bright's car rolls up to the main gate. Inside her car she is searching for her security card key. The GUARD notices and steps out of the booth. She rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Something wrong, Dr. Bright?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I can't find my key card.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Not a problem. Just let us know if it's lost and we'll make you a new one.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. He returns to the booth and the gate arm waves up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poorly painted sign in the window reads: "Transients Welcome."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Susan Bright's Argon ID, as an x-acto knife carefully cuts out the photo. O'Brien is hunched over, working diligently. The hotel room behind him is the kind of place where "cheap" would be the politically correct adjective. There are piles of nondescript scientific journals and reference texts everywhere. The walls around him are covered with clipped articles and we repeatedly glimpse the words nanotechnology, molecular engineering, assemblers and replicators. Using a colored marker he colors in one of the serious- looking black and white photos from the strip. There are only twelve colors in the set of markers so the result looks somewhere between Warhol and Turner-vision. He compares it to the color photo of Susan. Shrugs, good  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is not listening, her face as frozen as her picture her mind somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Without the nanobot it appears there will be no way to stabilize the waste entirely. Even at subzero temperatures it remains active. DR. NIGEL NEBBLEMAN is Susan's assistant. More nebbish than man.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: I wonder if there is a way we could catch that mouse. Susan? Susan, are you listening to me? She blinks.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What? Oh, I'm sorry, Nigel. I was just thinking...

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Aaabout...?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: This morning. I saw someone I haven't seen in a long time.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: A man?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I knew him when I was still in school.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. That's the funny thing about him. He's the kind of guy that you never know what he wants or what he might do to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien is moving against the general flow of traffic on crowded street. He notices a MAN in a business suit with a briefcase in one hand, a white Styrofoam cup of coffee in the other. The Man, apparently in a hurry, slugs down the last of t coffee, crumbles the cup in his fist and without a second thought, tosses the cup into the hedge.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Hey! The suit walks right past him, oblivious to O'Brien's outrage. O'Brien looks back at the cup and then the Man. A single word hisses from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Litterbug. He rushes to the hedge and seizes hold of the cup, then whirls back, chasing after the bug.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey, you! Hey, litterbug! Mr. Litterbug! He grabs the bug by the shoulder and spins him around.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but I believe you dropped this. The Litterbug, a very large litterbug, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG, (MAN)
dialogues.text: Yeah? So what?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: So what? So what? For starters, how about littering is a crime.

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: Haw-haw! Why don't you run off and find a cop and I'll wait right here.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Why don't you just put this in your pocket so when you see a garbage can you can put it where it belongs.

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: Why don't you just shove it up your ass! Haw-haw! The Litterbug starts walking away, but O'Brien continues to dog him.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What is it with you litterbugs? Is  it a territorial thing, marking your turf with your garbage?

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: You better quit pushing me, pal.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I just want to know what goes on in the mind of a litterbug. What chemical is secreted by your smooth brain that tells you, ‘It's okay, just chuck it'?

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: Look, asshole, I don't got time for this. I£ you got a problem, you better take care of it yourself.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh no, no, no. No can do. You enjoyed a tasty beverage and thus this receptacle becomes your responsibility and I don't care if it's a Styrofoam cup or the Exxon Valdez! You've got to learn to take responsibility!

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Make me throw it out?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever I have to do. Fists clench as they eye one another up and down until th Litterbug laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: Jee-sus! You're crazy as catshit! You win. Gimme the cup. Smiling, O'Brien starts to give him the cup.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Believe me, later on you'll feel a lot better about this... When suddenly the Litterbug seizes O'Brien's wrist, yanking him off balance as he pops him square in the nose A second blow to the gut doubles O'Brien over and a briefcase to the back of the head drops him to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: Later on you're going to feel a whole lot worse! Haw-haw.  He kicks him in the gut.

dialogues.speaker: LITTERBUG
dialogues.text: Next time mind your own business! He walks away as O'Brien squeezes the styrofoam CUP, CRACKING it in his fist.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No good stinking litterbug...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is still talking to Nebbleman.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Do you remember about five years ago, that uh... incident at Purnell Labs?

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. They were working on molecular assemblers, too, weren't they?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: They also tried using viral R.N.A. as the bonding element.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: That's right. C.D.C. found out and closed them down... Susan looks into the mouse cage as Nebbleman remembers th rest.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, somebody broke in and stole the samples, one of those animal rights groups, right? I remember now, they freed all the monkeys which caused that huge pileup on the Massachusetts Turnpike, right?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. But it wasn't a group. It was one man.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: That's the guy? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: And you think he knows what we're doing here?  She nods again.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A security card slides through the gate box. The arm raises and Daniel O'Brien drives in, waving to th security man who absently waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We GLIDE THROUGH the frosted glass and out THROUGH the inverted letters spelling, "SECURITY."

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: So you think this psycho- environmentalist character stole your security key to break into the lab? The head of Argon Security sitting behind his enormous desk is D.T. SIM, a little guy with something to prove. His silent partner is Doby, an enormous man with the face of a mastiff.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It might be paranoia, but I've never lost my keycard before.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: ‘Paranoia is what separates the secured from the unsecured.' He smiles, enjoying his own cleverness.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Just a little saying we've got in the security business, Dr. Bright. We get paid to be paranoid. We worry so you don't have to. He lights a stogie.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: A lot of people think security is just a job, but for me it's a way of life. It's a state of mind. He blows a cloud of smoke into the air.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: If this nutcase did take it and has  half a brain, he'd use it right away, before we could invalidate it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, that is what I was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: In fact, would it be safe to say, based on your general knowledge of this character, that he is already in the building?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, he might be.

dialogues.speaker: COLORED ID
dialogues.text: that O'Brien forged, clipped to the pocket of a lab coat. We notice that he also inked in some dark glasses and a moustache. smiling, nodding, he moves through the busy corridors wit a sense of inconspicuous conspicuousness. Susan appears from around a corner, walking toward him as he turns away. Something about the tall moustached man catches her eye when --

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Susan! Susan! Nebbleman hurries to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: What did security say?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: They'll in validate the key. Probably nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, you got another problem.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The replicators?

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Worse. Mrs. Argon wants to talk to you. She's waiting in the lab.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: This day just keeps going from bad to worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM INSIDE the mouse cage, we see Poppy looking DOWN AT us. Her perfect red lips slightly curling into a sneer.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Vermin...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I help you, Mrs. Argon? As Susan enters the lab, Nebbleman fades back and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: I spoke to Dr. Argon this morning and he remains frustrated over the loss of the original nanobot.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I am aware of Dr. Argon's frustrations.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: He believes that the second nanobot should be ready for testing by now. Susan does not want to hear this now.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Argon is going to have to muster a little patience. I was rushed into testing the nanobot on that mouse and now we are dealing with a toxic waste that has the potential to make Three Mile Island look like spilled milk. Susan stares daggers.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances, I can't fathom what makes Dr. Argon think we are ready for anything bigger. If C.N.N., or hell, if the E.P.A. knew what was in my basement --

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Is that a threat, Dr. Bright?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Look, as I have said and will continue to say, the instability of the assembler waste remains my priority --

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: While you remain on the staff at Argon Laboratories, your priorities  will always be the same as Dr. Argon's priorities. I imagine that is a simple enough equation for a bright girl like you to figure out. Poppy smiles. Susan suppresses the urge to smash her head with a microscope.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: If you don't have any questions, I'll let you get back to doing your job.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Just one question. Since Dr. Argon no longer has feeling below his waist, how is it that you're still able to do your job? Poppy glances up at the security camera in the far corner She leans close to Susan and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: I could have you fired right now.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You won't. That's why you're whispering. Poppy glares at her, then spins on her heels and leaves. Still fuming, Susan turns to a special computerized, vault-like machine which is the nanobot freon-containment system. At the top, there is a sealed plate that is connected to an electron microscope. She touches the plate, almost lovingly, letting her anger drain away. Nebbleman skulks back in.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: He wants another test? She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: I bet he hasn't read a single report we've written on the waste problem.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I hope you're right. I'd feel a lot worse if he had read them and just didn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What I've always done. As long as I'm the only one who can build the nanobot, I'm the only one who can say when it should be tested. As they return to work, we RISE UP TO the unblinking eye of the security camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The security booth is Sim's world; he is intimate with every detail of each small framed monitor.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Hey, Dobe... Ever wonder if this is how God feels looking down on us? Doby says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Yeah, me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun, a brilliant ball of lemon yellow, slowly begins to curdle -- Transmogrifying into a full moon, pale and winter blue against a night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark room filled with barrels labeled, "EXPLOSIVE

dialogues.speaker: MATERIALS
dialogues.text: A barrel lid cracks open. Two eyes peek out. O'Brien unfolds himself, awkwardly climbing out of the empty barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien slithers up the stairs, clinging to every shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a ghost, he glides down the dark empty halls, moving only when the surveillance cameras pan away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOOR HICCUPS and O'Brien slips inside. On hands and knees he crawls toward the center of the la where the nanobot is stored. Again we PEER OUT THROUGH the wire mesh of the mouse cage O'Brien's head POPS UP IN FRONT of us.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh no, P.O.W.s. He ducks down just as the camera sweeps overhead. He pops back up. Opening the cage, he frees all of the little mice.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Never leave a man behind. He grabs the last one, ducking under the arc of the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a flash of white in the corner of Susan's lab.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Did you see that? Doby nods.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Looked like a... mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cage is empty. O'Brien finds the security panel of the nanobot containment system. He sprinkles graphite dust on the keypad. When he blows on the dust, four numbers remain covered: 1-6-8-9. From his pocket he pulls out a folded paper. It is filled with a list of all the numbers relevant to Susan's life such as birthdays, phone numbers and significant dates. His thumb stops at "August 6th, 1991. Birth of Nanobot."

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Never good at remembering numbers, were you, Susie? He types the date and the pressurized SEALS GASP. The plate rises, revealing a glass tube filled with a sapphir blue liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your baby, ain't it? He is about to touch it when the lab DOOR suddenly swings OPEN. He ducks. Holding his breath, he waits. The room is silent. Slowly, quietly, he peeks out. A flashlight blinks near him and he ducks back down. He hears a WHISPER. Panicking, he starts to creep toward the door when a beam of light suddenly pools around him.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Look what we caught here. O'Brien can't see because of the light in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: One big muther of a mouse. O'Brien bolts, running straight into Doby's chest. A giant fist hammers down onto the top of his skull as hi eyes roll up into his head.

dialogues.speaker: ON NIGHTMARE
dialogues.text: trapped beneath searing laboratory overhead lights, Argon's hideous face HOVERS OVER us, a cracked lipless smile revealing ulcerous gums and stained teeth.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: I've been waiting for something like this my whole life. The voices warp through the watery space.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Bad boy got caught with his hand in the cookie jar. The faces float over O'Brien like disembodied heads.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: You should have stayed in jail, pal. Argon grips O'Brien's head under the chin. Poised betwee his fingers is a gleaming stainless steel hypodermic needle.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: For every environmentalist, anti- industrialist, animal activist that has shoved their myopic, protectionist cause-of-the-month crap down my throat, I shove this down yours! He sticks the needle into O'Brien's neck. O'Brien's eyes flutter, the voices and faces stretching away. Argon's thumb depresses the plunger.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: You sure you know what you're doing, Icky? INSIDE the hypo, blood blossoms all around us as the sapphire fluid containing the nanobot is injected into O'Brien. We RUSH with blurred speed INTO his blood stream as we se the nanobot; a microbiotic machine that resembles a snowflake. As it bounces from protein cell to cell, falling AWAY FRO us, it begins to blur as we hear what sounds like MUZAK. The shapes FOCUS again as we realize that we are now LOOKING DOWN INTO the aisle of a grocery store. The two parts of the nanobot become O'Brien and Susan joined together by the grocery cart they are pushing.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: It is the 1970s. O'Brien is a granola hippie activist type, extra crunchy. Susan still loves Oreo cookies.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Nanotechnology is going to change the world, Danny. I'm telling you in ten maybe twenty years, life is going to be a totally new kind of experience. O'Brien is not listening, repulsed by the stock lining th shelves.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: And what I love about molecular science is the way it revolutionizes how we have to think. It unifies  the entire world on a single level. Everything is completely connected. Sometimes I can really feel it, everything around us, just a small part of a whole. It's really wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: We'll see? What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: We'll see how wonderful it is after you spend the next twenty years making Agent Orange.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: God, Daniel, I'm not going to make Agent Orange.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You think the chemists that invented Agent Orange twenty years ago were in school saying, ‘Boy, I really got some good ideas for a highly toxic incendiary defoliant.' You think Oppenheimer was dreaming about mushroom clouds before the war? She tries to ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: We've had this conversation already, Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: All I'm saying is that the companies that have money for the kind of research you're interested in, have money because that's what they're interested in! Money! She stops the cart.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I brought the whole thing up! If you're gonna flip your wig --

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I can't help it, Suze. It's this place. You know how I get in these stores. They freak me out. All these tiny boxes, little cans filled with eight syllable God knows what.  He grabs a can of Spam.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Look at this. They've taken all the food out of food. When you start talking about the future, this is what I see. Huge vats of Spam. You are what you eat and they're turning us into Spam-people. He shoves the can back into the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You think it's a coincidence that they have all these aisles lined up like this, like a little maze! We're all lab rats running through their maze, pulling lever A or lever B, each designed to create some kind of bio-chemical dependency. All the while they're everywhere, watching us, two-way mirrors, surveillance cameras, nodding to each other, making little notes.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Am I? Look! Right there! That's exactly what I am talking about. A little BOY is trying to get a box of Trix cereal from a shelf that is too high.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Lever A... He jumps several times, unable to grab the economy-sized box. O'Brien walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Daniel! Don't -- Oh no. The tips of the kid's fingers are slowly coaxing the box from the edge.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Let me help you, kid. The Kid's face widens into a smile until O'Brien pushes the box back.

dialogues.speaker: KID, (BOY)
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You don't want this.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You have no idea what this is doing to your body.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: I like Trix!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Daniel, give him the Trix.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Susan, this is the future of America here.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Trix are for kids! O'Brien grabs a box of Shredded Wheat.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Here, kid, this is great stuff. Why don't you give it a try?

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: I want Trix! Mommy! The Boy's wail swells unnaturally loud as we rise up, DISTORTING, as it becomes -- The PRESSURIZING of the TEST TANK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien jerks awake. He is inside a dark steel capsule. There is a WET SUCKING NOISE as the hoses are opened and the white assembler fluid begins pumping into the tank.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Argon watches the gauges climbing on the tanks with a mad gleam in his eye. Poppy stares at the computer flickering through the model simulation.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Icky, this is so exciting.  Sim looks a bit nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: How long do you leave him in there?

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Until he's done. He laughs until the tank shivers. The whole unit is now sizzling hot. A coolant line bursts. Each of them backs away as the tank vibrates under mounting pressure, like a water balloon that is ready to burst.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: +e. Icky? The TANK EXPLODES, splitting open like a can of whipped cream. We see the world THROUGH the eyes of O'Brien as he rises from the burbling marshmallow-amnion. Everything has a sense of UNNATURAL VISCOSITY as if reality had been remad with molasses. The room CURVES and WARPS, our eyes like carnival mirrors We see a DISTORTED ARGON staring at us in awe.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: My God... it works. Now we see O'Brien. He has been completely polymerized, his entire body shifting and flowing like a drunken wave machine. The rubbery flesh of his face looks too heavy, hanging slack. His eyes bulge and loll as he tries to focus.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Grab him! Hurry! Grab him! Doby is the closest and he snatches O'Brien's arm. O'Brien reacts, yanking his arm which thins to a strand o spaghetti and whips free. O'Brien stumbles backwards, quivering like a Jell-O Slink until his bare foot, which seems more a puddle than a foot, lands on the main floor drain. His leg slips immediately through the sieve as he slaps down to the floor, one leg sprawled out in front of him. He blinks.  Then the rest of him falls through. Sim grabs at the pile of clothes covering the drain but Daniel O'Brien is gone. FROM BELOW the drain we LOOK UP at Argon and the others staring down.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: It's a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: It's an organic-polymerization. Behind them the tank core continues to melt down, gelatinous waste splattering the room.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Icky! What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Who cares! We've got to find him! Hurry! His chair heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A six inch pipe opening GROANS with the sound of STRETCHING RUBBER. Fingers suddenly reach out and grab the edge of the hole. There are a series of CARTOON-LIKE SOUNDS as O'Brien pull himself out, emerging from the opening like toothpaste. After a struggle he pops free, snapping into normal human proportions. Cradling his head, he stands up in the corrugated metal drain. Unsure of what has happened or why he is naked, he stumbles out into the creek, his bare feet squishing into the muddy water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon throbs overhead in a sky of dark crushed velvet. Sim and Doby's flashlight beams dart and bounce as they sweep the compound. They find the drain pipe and Sim throws his beam down it careful not to get his shoes muddy.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Ah for the love of God, I ain't going in there. He looks at Doby. INT.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: You check it out. Poppy and Argon ride up in the elevator that connects the main lab to Argon Tower. INT.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: It works, Poppy. It works, it works!

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Now, Icky, I don't need you winding yourself up. I need you focused and in control.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: But, Poppy, you don't know what this means --

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: You don't either. We won't know anything until we find that guy and find out if he's alive or what.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true. We have to find him, run tests, determine if the polymerization is stable.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: In the meantime, we're going to need someone to deal with that mess in the lab. I don't think we should call Dr. Bright.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Oh no. No. We'll get her assistant. What's-his-name? Nebbishman?

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Nebbleman. Nigel Nebbleman enters the building. He is wearing a  raincoat over his pajamas that are covered with small bunny rabbits. Poppy is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Dr. Nebbleman, thank God you're here! In her high heels she is taller than him and when they embrace, his head lays against her ample bosom.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: I've been nearly hysterical with fright. Thank God you came. I feel so much better that you're here.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: What happened? Poppy leads him to the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: As I told you on the phone, there's been an accident. A terrible accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Nebbleman's voice crack with panic, as he rushes towards the double doors of the lab.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my God. Oh my God. The moment he bursts in and sees the ruptured test tank melting into the white mucous of the assembler waste -- He faints.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nebbleman lifts his face from the paper bag he was breathing in. Panic is cracking his voice.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Alright. Okey-dokey. Now, we need the nanobot. The nanobot that initiated the reaction. Once we have that we can stabilize the meltdown. Simple really. No problem.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: The nanobot is gone. Nebbleman's voice rises several octaves.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Gone? What do you mean gone? Gone where? His knees buckle as Argon does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Dr. Nebbleman, we are scientists, you and I and men of science are not concerned with emotions and opinions. We are concerned with facts. Nebbleman is hyperventilating, like a mouse caught in a glue trap.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: The fact is, that the milk has been spilled and now we need you to tell us how to clean it up.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Cleaned up? It can't be cleaned up! Without the nanobot the waste can't be stabilized! That's what we've been trying to tell you! The only thing we can do is run! Run! Run! Argon signals to Poppy. Poppy slaps Nebbleman. Nebbleman is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Facts, Dr. Nebbleman. Facts. You've been using cryogenics to control the waste from the mouse experiment, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, yes. The replicators are not as active at low temperatures.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Then perhaps we can use liquid nitrogen to keep the meltdown under control.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: That might work.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Poppy, order the trucks from the Gary plant. And we're going to need a containment crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A containment crew is going to attract a lot of attention.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: You're right. Place a call to our friends at the network and to Mr. Joplin at the E.P.A.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: How did this happen? How did the nanobot activate the assembler fluid? If I'm going to help, I have to know what happened. Argon studies Nebbleman for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: All right, Dr. Nebbleman. Come with me and I'll tell you everything. Motoring his chair around, Argon leads Nigel to the conservatory. The elevator slides open and Sim gets out leading a muddy Doby.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Mr. Sim, did you find him? Sim has O'Brien's wad of clothes tucked under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: No, but if he's alive I think I know where he might go. He holds up the key to O'Brien's hotel room; the plastic key chain stamped, "Admiral Hotel."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muddy bare footprint, black grime against green shag. We PULL BACK and see another, then another, the tracks leading toward the white light of the bathroom door. We CLOSE IN ON the bilious white of the steam, the warble of O'Brien whimpering and shivering even in the scalding water. He begins to sneeze and cough as if something were tickling the back of his throat. He snorts at it, inhaling through his nose, trying to suck it out. Finally, he spits a clear silicon-like wad of phlegm that remains connected to his mouth by a long rubbery strand.  He spits at it, and it stretches until he flicks it off with his hand. It hangs on the wall for a moment like a sticky rubber slug before being swept down the tub drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We RISE THROUGH the floor drain. Wearing a special insulated contamination suit, Nebbleman is on hands and knees examining the lab floor. He lifts a hand and we see an impression that gradually fades as if the ground were a sheet of foam. He slaps it hard and the tile ripples like a waterbed.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Oh God, it's worse than I thought. He runs for the door leaving a trail of footprints.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Get that crew in here. Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the lab a flurry of activity erupts. Thick hoses are attached to the belly of giant tanker trucks. Brilliant portable kliegs illuminate the grounds like a ball park. Men in bulbous insulated space suits milk the tankers filling scuba-like canisters that are worn on their backs The bold letters on the back of the tanker read: "WARNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly we MOVE TOWARD the " in "NITROGEN." It OPENS in front of us like a yawning tunnel which we DESCEND INTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien is in a deep sleep, mouth wide open, his breathin rasped. Turning his face deeper into his pillow, he is suddenly unable to breathe. He sucks for air with a strained gurgle. His eyes pop open, still suffocating and he bolts upright. We see that his neck has been twisted around like a knotted sheet.  His head spins around and snaps back into place.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Mommy? He is dizzy and confused. He rubs his head and neck, panic seeping into his expression as he begins to remembe last night's events. He looks down seeing the muddy footprints on the carpet. O'Brien touches his neck where he was injected.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Uh oh. Suddenly the door whaps open, Sim and Doby FILLING the FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. O'Brien! Still in his underwear, O'Brien jumps from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You! I remember you!

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: I'm real touched. Now get your Sunday's on. We're going for a ride. He throws O'Brien's pants at him.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What? I'm not going anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Oh yes you are!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I get it. You're the goon fetch boy. The zookeeper Argon calls in when one of his guinea pigs gets loose.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: That's right. Sim opens his coat showing O'Brien his firearm.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Only this ain't no tranquilizer gun. Now let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, pissboy! You tell Argon he can call my lawyer. Sim reaches for his gun.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: The hard way it is! O'Brien heaves a Yellow Pages at Sim which sails past his head. He leaps behind the coffee table. Sim points the gun at O'Brien's head.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Not smart! You forgot I've got the gun! O'Brien, on his toes, keeps the table in between him and Sim.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Then let's see you use it, bucko! Dr. Argon's not going to take it very well that you killed his experiment. Sim snorts.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Doby? He waves Doby to the other side of the table. But before they can grab him, O'Brien spins away from Sim and bolts for the window. He throws it open, yelling.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Help! Somebody help me! Sim and Doby tackle him from behind.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: I'll take care of this. Hold him. Sim raises his gun high into the air --

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Lights out. And brings it down on O'Brien's head. It rebounds off of O'Brien's skull which in turn rebounds off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Ow!  Sim raises it again.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: I said -- Lights out! And again smashes O'Brien in the head to no effect.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Ouchhh! Cut it out! Sim looks at the gun then repeatedly brings a hail of blows onto O'Brien whose head bounces off the gun and floor like a dribbling basketball. O'Brien grabs his head as Sim tires.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Jesus! Panting, Sim holsters his gun.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Get his legs. O'Brien lunges, grabbing the window sill as the two men each take a leg.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No! They heave at his legs trying to wrench him from the sill O'Brien's body raises off the floor. Struggling and straining with all of his might, O'Brien looks up to secure his grip and his eyes go wide. O'Brien's arms have begun to stretch. He looks back over his shoulder to see that his legs also have begun to stretch. Sim and Doby seem to notice at the same time, that they have stretched O'Brien halfway to the door.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Holy shit! The two men let go of O'Brien's legs and he is flung like a slingshot out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Holy shit! He cartwheels in the space outside the window, splayed an flailing spastically. The people, nine floors down, scream as O'Brien plummets toward them. O'Brien's tearing eyes clamp shut in the face of onrushi pavement, a faint sound caught in his ear. An ascending twang, like a tightening guitar string. Whump. O'Brien hits the ground, unsure if he's alive of dead. A woman screams. He rattles his head and opens his eyes. There is a woman in front of him, her face buried in her hands. O'Brien tries to stand.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh God -- am I dead? Hearing him, the woman peers out from shielding fingers. She looks up at his arm and screams again. O'Brien is confused. Slowly he turns, following her gaze up, up, up. His arm stretches up to the ninth story window, like a safety line, his hand still gripping the sill. His face contorts in horror. O'Brien screams, letting go. Loopy wet spaghetti strands collect on the sidewalk in a pile as his arm falls. The crowd collectively inhales. The hand plops on the top of the pile like some strange garnish. O'Brien whimpers. A CAR SCREECHES to a stop and O'Brien jumps back at the sound. As he lands, his body jerking to the side, his arm suddenly begins reeling in like a fishing line. The crowd's heads swivel back and forth watching the arm snap back to normal in a loud whip-crack.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh God. He cradles the arm under the stare of the gaper's block. Chest heaving, he stumbles back two steps. He shoots a look up at his apartment window. The shadows of Sim and Doby look down. He bolts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sim and Doby watch open-mouthed as O'Brien disappears dow the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to take some explaining. Sim whips out his cellular phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Argon? It's Sim.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Sim? Do you have him? He's alive?

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, he's alive. Technically.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And you have him?

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: We lost him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppy sits atop the massive ebony slab of Argon's desk, the phone pressed to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: Here, you tell him. She smiles and hands the phone to Argon.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Mr. Sim, you know I sooner kill the messenger then listen to bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sim swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Don't worry there, Dr. Argon. He gave us the slip, in a manner of speaking. But we're definitely closing in on him. Doby frowns.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Sim, when you do locate him. Do not scare him off again. Just watch him, I think you can handle that. Right, Mr. Sim?

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: You got it, Dr. Argon.  He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Shit! Sim slams his hands on the desk and looks down to find th pictures of Dr. Bright, a heart encircling it.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are LOOKING THROUGH the LENS of a local network news camera on location outside Argon Labs. The CAMERA RACK FOCUSES and PANS TO network reporter, SPENCER LAMM.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Tawney, I'm standing in front of the security station just outside of Argon Labs in Calumet City. Since seven o'clock this morning, when security guards barred the weekend staff here at Argon Labs, rumors have been circulating as to the nature of the accident that occurred here last night. He looks over his shoulder as an unmarked tanker rolls past the security gate.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: All we know for sure is that at 9:30 a.m., two sedans carrying the county sheriff and men who have been identified as high-ranking officials of the E.P.A. entered the Argon offices and have not come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PULL BACK REVEALING the reporter on television in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We expect a statement some time today, but until then we can only speculate that whatever did happen here, which has crews working around the clock, no one was prepared for. This has been Spencer Lamm live at Argon Labs. Susan drops her coffee cup when she hears the name. She rushes to turn up the volume but the special report is over. She is searching the other stations when someone POUNDS her door. THROUGH the peep-hole she sees O'Brien, his face WARPED b the WIDE-ANGLE LENS.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh shit... With the chain still on, she opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Susie! You gotta help me!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Daniel, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Please, Susan! I need help! Something is wrong with me!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Daniel, I'm a physicist, not a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No, something is really wrong... look! He stuffs his arms into the three-inch slot between the door and the jamb then squeezes his body and head through Susan steps back, her mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You... you... She points at him then at the television.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: They did it to me!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The nanobot. As O'Brien spits the story out his gestures become more animated.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Last night, Argon's goons grabbed me, the big one hit me, probably did severe cranio-sacral damage and bam, I drop to the floor, and then Argon was there, and it became like a bad dream. Everyone was laughing as he stuck this big needle in my neck and  then I'm not sure what happened but I came to in a metal tank and they drowned me with white goo and I thought I was dead, everything soft and blurry and the next thing I know I wake up back in my hotel and Argon's goons bust in and we fight and I fall out the window and again I thought I was a goner, but I hit the ground and I bounce and I look up and my arm is really really long and I know, I know I shouldn't have been in your lab but Jesus Christ, Susan, feel my skin, feel it! It feels like plastic! He reaches his arm across the room and she feels his hand

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: -+. just like the mouse.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Mouse? What mouse?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: My first organic-polymerization was a lab mouse.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What happened to it?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. He jerks his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You don't know?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It escaped from the lab before we could finish the experiment.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: But you've polymerized single-celled bacteria and the fruit flies, I know you have.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Then you must have at some point tried to reverse the procedure. She nods but it is not the kind of nod he was hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no, no! You've got to be able to fix me! Please, Susan, tell me you can make me normal again!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Once the subject was polymerized we were unable to reassemble the original organic structure. His legs go wobbly. She slaps him;

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh God, please! This can't be happening! I can't be plastic! A plastic man?!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Daniel!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I'ma plastic man! A plastic man! his chin flaps back and forth before snapping into place. INT.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: We don't have time for hysterics.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: We don't?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What has happened to you is nothing compared to what is going to happen to Calumet City if we don't hurry. She hands him a glass of water and drops several pills into his open palm.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What are these?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Mostly caffeine diuretics. Help you go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The nanobot is still inside you. It's programmed to exit through the urinary tract. We need it as soon as possible, so swallow those.  He stares at the gleaming plastic capsules.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Pills... you know how I feel about pills.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: If you don't want to do it this way, I can remove it surgically. He gobbles them down.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Why do we need it?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The nanobot is the only thing that can stabilize the waste.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What waste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLAST of icy smoke COUGHS from the NOZZLE of a LIQUID NITROGEN PACK. Two men in their heavy insulated space suits work over th broken chamber where O'Brien was polymerized dousing the assembler waste with their liquid nitrogen hoses. The lab has become a winter wonderland. The lights have quit and the room is lit only by the gree and yellow fluoro-glow sticks worn on the helmets of the workers. The assembler waste, covered in frost, bubbles and churns lava-like and the two men FIRE another burst of FROZEN GAS. FRANK TATER crosses to the door, his boots CRUNCHING ON the ICY FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Nigel Nebbleman, also wearing an insulated suit, wait for him.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, Frank? Frank lifts his helmet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I've never seen anything like it.  We can't get a handle on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is in this poorly-lit basement that Dr. Bright does most of her work.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: To put is simply, the nanobot inside you is a microscopic machine encoded with information like a strand of messenger R.N.A. that is programmed to synthesize your molecules with the polyisoprenes of the assembler fluid, rebuilding your entire organic system on a molecular level.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: That was 'simple'? She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The nanobot combined your molecules with the plastic molecules in the white assembler fluid, so that on a molecular level you now have more in common with a Good Year tire than a human being.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The problem is the by-product created by the process.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: The waste. As they talk, we MOVE ALONG a stainless steel table where Susan is conducting a series of tests with the waste. These tests reveal the stages of molecular deterioration caused by the waste.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Only part of the molecule from the assembler fluid bonds to your molecules. The part left over is a highly charged unstable molecule we call a replicator. She puts on a pair of protective gloves and grabs one of the test cylinders.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The effect these replicators have on any matter, organic or inorganic, is similar to the molecular deterioration caused by nuclear radiation. The PRESSURIZED SEAL SIGHS open and she pours the content out.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I've been measuring the levels of deterioration. As with radiation, the more exposure, the more damage it does. A white egg rolls into her gloved palm.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I dropped a single replicator in with this egg two days ago. She hurls the egg at the ground and quite naturally at this point, it bounces back. He catches it. It squishes between his fingers like a racquetball. He pulls at it. It stretches like Silly- Putty.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: It's polymerized like me? She takes the egg back.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The replicators start off like assemblers, but the replicators never stabilize.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What happens? She opens another cylinder and pours it out. And oval- shaped wad of gray SLUDGE SPLATS onto the lid.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: That was an egg?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Three days ago it was.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What do these replicators do to people?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: With enough exposure, the same thing they do to everything else.  He swallows hard, watching the egg-wad cling like snot from the lid, as she reseals the cylinder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer Lamm is on the scene which continues to escalate.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Here in Calumet City, a bomb has just dropped. Through anonymous sources, we have learned that Argon Labs may have been the victim of an attack by a radical environmentalist group. No such group has yet to claim responsibility but we are expecting confirmation of these rumors at a press conference scheduled this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan puts the cylinder of slime back into a large freeze unit filled with similar cylinders.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: So right now there's little replicators spreading throughout Argon's lab?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Isn't it already too late then? She shakes her head, opening a final cylinder.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: There is a forty-eight hour period during which the waste can be stabilized. The contents slide into her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The nanobot will start a chain reaction and transform the replicators through a double hydrogen bond, creating an ionic solid instead of a polymer. The egg seems fossilized, half way to becoming the wad of slime. She hands it to O'Brien. It is as fragile as a glass spider web.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Yet another miracle of modern science. She ignores the sarcasm laced in that comment.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I think while we're waiting, we had better run some basic diagnostics on you.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You're the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street a dark Lincoln ominously glides to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sim settles back, watching the building for any sign of O'Brien.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Now we wait. Both he and Doby are licking ice cream cones. For a moment it is the only sound in the car.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: Darn good cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien is sitting on a table, his shirt off, while Susan listens to his lungs with a stethoscope.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Breathe deep. The AIR RUSHES out.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Lungs sound fine. You didn't have any pre-existing physical conditions, did you? Allergies? Infections?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No, why? She removes the stethoscope and grabs the light scope.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: My theory is that during the polymerization the nanobot should correct any malformed or defective  molecules. Open. His mouth stretches impossibly wide for an amazing view o the glands at the back of his throat. Looks fine.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That theory is the reason Argon has been pushing me to test the second nanobot. He believes it's the only thing that will save him. She picks up a hypodermic needle.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to run a few sample blood tests to get an idea of how stable your condition is. O'Brien is beginning to bounce a bit, the caffeine pumpin through his veins.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Sure. You're the doc. Tearing open a needle package, she inserts it into the plastic hypo.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Hold still. She fights to poke the needle through his resilient skin. When the sliver of metal pops through, tiny Superball bubbles of blood bounce into the cartridge like ping-pong balls in a bingo machine.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Amazing. She fills another cartridge when he begins to chatter, hi rubbery teeth vibrating against each other.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No, no, I just feel wired! His whole body begins to twitch and ripple.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It's probably the caffeine. Suddenly he realizes he has to go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Whoa! I gotta go! Right now! She slips the needle out and he bolts off the table.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Wait! She grabs a glass beaker as his hand shoots back and snag it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bursts in, fumbles with the beaker and his zipper, the lets it rip.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Ahbh... His eyes close as we hear him filling the beaker. It is a STRANGE SOUND; more like a solid than a liquid. The sound bothers him and he looks down. What he sees terrifies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is looking into a microscope at the blood samples when he comes tearing down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Susan!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What? What's wrong? He throws the beaker onto the table as if it were contagious.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Look at this!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What about it! He sticks a stirring rod into it and pulls it out. The contents are extremely viscous, like rubber cement. A wispy strand dangles from the end of the stick.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Just look at it!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The polymerization probably synthesized into a kind of methyl- cyanoacrylate. So what's wrong?  He looks as if he is about to cry.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: That's not biodegradable. She can't stop herself from laughing.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, real funny. Yuk-yuk. Let's laugh at everything a man believes in.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Daniel, but you have to admit it's pretty ironic that you of all people would be the first man ever polymerized. It's got to mean something.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Means? Oh no. We won't know what it means until the end of the story and maybe then it won't seem quite as funny to you, Doctor Frankenstein! The smile disappears.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Just giving credit where credit is due.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You have no one to blame but yourself.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Blame the victim.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Victim my ass! You stole my security key and used it to break into my lab to do who knows what kind of damage! Maybe this is the end of the story and you finally got what you deserved!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: This is what I deserve for trying to protect the world from a madman and his mercenary physicists?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're not protecting the world,  you're obstructing progress!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I don't consider uncontrollable toxic waste progress!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: And I'm sure you thought Columbus was going to sail off the edge of the world!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: But lo and behold he found another world that progress could annihilate!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Come on, I don't see you living in a cave!

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: And I don't see you sunbathing at Chernobyl! She stops first, smiling, caught by an odd sense of deja vu. He smiles, feeling the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Just like old times.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Old times. There is an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I want you to know that I really appreciate you helping me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came to me for help. They aren't sure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I feel very emotional right now. A bit out of control.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Probably the caffeine.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Do you have something to bring me down?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN JOPLIN, high-ranking EPA official, listens as Dr. Nebbleman tries to explain what has happened. Argon and Poppy are also in the office.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: The nanobot is a molecular machine. It uses the assembler fluid to polymerize a whole system of carbon- based molecules as in, say, a human body. His eyes shift nervously to Argon who nods encouragingly.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Once it's complete, the waste from the assembler fluid is left destabilized with groups of highly charged attractors capable of bonding to any carbon molecule exposed for a long enough period.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Hold on, son. Are you saying that they can bond to people?

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: With enough exposure, it appears they can bond to anything.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Well, what will they do to people? Nebbleman glances nervously at Argon.

dialogues.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, at this time, I mean that is to say, it is difficult to project --

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Look, John, nobody wants to find out what happens. That's why you're here. We need your help on this one and that's why that suitcase is here. Poppy opens it for him. The root of all evil. Stacks and stacks of it.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Let me assure you, Dr. Argon, the E.P.A. is, as always, on your side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is later. O'Brien is stretched out on the sofa in a valium fugue; his long supple limbs conform to the curves of the cushions, dangling over all sides. His head is on the floor, neck distending down from the arm rest. Mid-snore, he wakes up, yawning. From his upside down view, he sees the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: «+. food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is looking through a microscope trying to find the nanobot.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Come on, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien opens the fridge. Rubber-necking, he looks inside while his body lies on th couch.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Hey, Susie! I'm hungry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is still glued to the microscope.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Damn it! She pounds her fist against the lab table.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh oh. I remember that temper.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Daniel, I didn't hear you come down... She turns and finds his head almost floating, perched on his neck arching erectly up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nanobot... it's not here...

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: It's still inside me? She nods watching his head bobbing cobra-like around her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You'll have to start drinking fluids, lots of fluids. She reaches out and touches his neck. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How far can you stretch?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing in the square of rich green grass, O'Brien looks up. He lifts his head and takes a deep breath, staring at his fingers spread against the blue expanse above him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Reach as high as you can. From ABOVE his hand, we see O'Brien nod nervously and begin to reach -- His face, Dr. Bright, the square lawn, the house, one by one seem to FALL AWAY -- Spreading out under the hand until the ground seems like the sky did moments ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sim and Doby lean into the front windshield of the black Lincoln, watching O'Brien's arm telescope into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: SIM
dialogues.text: That's why I love the security biz. Just when you think you've seen everything... He whips out his cellular. Dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Bright stares, open-mouthed, at the arm-ribbon as it rises impossibly like a kite.  She turns and sees O'Brien's body thinning, almost spooling out like a ball of yarn until his pants fall dow to his ankles. He feels the draft and turns to see her looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Oops. He grabs his pants as his arm returns with a RUSHING soun that ends with a loud rubbery CLAP.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I'll end up back in jail for indecent exposure. Dr. Bright nods vaguely, already lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What? She reaches out and feels his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scalpel saws through several strands of O'Brien's hair.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That should do it. His hair is shorter and she drops the strands with the rest of it, into a Ziploc bag.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to go out for a while. I want to take the blood samples to a lab that has the equipment I need.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: What did you want my hair for?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Something else I want to try. She puts the Ziploc bag in her briefcase and gets the blood samples.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I could go with you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I think it would be better for me to go alone. I'm sure Sim is looking for you. Just sit tight. I'll bring you back a pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cheese.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I was hoping you were over that. Remember to keep drinking fluids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppy, Argon and John Joplin are inside, as it pulls up outside Cook County courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
dialogues.text: How do I look? She is dressed in a two-piece PVC business suit; smart ye slutty. Argon smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ARGON
dialogues.text: Positively paradoxical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Brien is stretched out on the couch watching "The Itchy and Scratchy Show" on the television. He is drinking a two liter bottle of Coke without stopping. His Adam's apple bobs like a cartoon as he swallows. We can hear the COKE FIZZING in his distending stomach. It swells like a water balloon. Finishing the bottle, he tosses it into a garbage bag filled with empties. He lets out a super hero style belch then settles back, chuckling at the cartoon. Itchy gets a frying pan to the face. On the table, there is a vase filled with dried flowers. He empties it and with the vase walks over to the hall mirror. Slowly he forces the vase over his head. When he yanks it off, his head keeps the shape. He starts to laugh and his face pops back. There is a series of GURGLING sounds from his STOMACH as he realizes he has to go. He bolts for the bathroom, his hand whipping out for the beaker.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: He's finished and he sets the beaker back where it was. He thinks and mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Technically, I don't even have to "go! to the bathroom... We MOVE CLOSER and CLOSER to the beaker, THROUGH the glas INTO the golden fluid -- SHRINKING as we MOVE THROUGH the murk DOWN TO the MOLECULAR LEVEL where we SQUEEZE BETWEEN chains of elastomers -- And FIND the nanobot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press room is small, considering the sizable horde that is packed wall to wall, shoulder to shoulder, to see CEO Poppy Argon and the EPA deliver their statements. The WHITE NOISE of press CHATTER reaches a fevered pitch as the county sheriff leads Poppy Argon and several EPA officials in. John Joplin steps to the podium and the crowd noise dies. He leans into the bouquet of microphones, opening his statement.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. The intent of... A MAN shouts from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm John Joplin, special investigator for the E.P.A. The intent of this press conference is twofold. Number one, to affirm that there has been a slight chemical spill at Argon Labs. Cleanup is already under way. FLASHBULBS BURST.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: And number two, that the E.P.A. in conjunction with members of Illinois County Sheriff Department and the F.B.I. have concluded that the spill was not accidental.  The press begins to titter and Joplin raises his voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Last night, Argon Labs was the target of what can only be described as a terrorist act. Another barrage of flashes.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: The single assailant sabotaged certain chemical storage units, creating the toxic spill.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Are there any suspects?

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: The only thing I can say is that the perpetrator was photographed by Argon Security cameras. The rest of the details of the case, until a later time, will be kept in the highest confidentiality. Thank you. The press erupts: "Who was it? Was it a group? Have you identified him?" Joplin's eyebrows go up and he turns back to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: JOPLIN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. His name's Daniel O'Brien. The entourage begins to file out under a barrage of questions. Spencer Lamm fights to get his crew in front of Poppy.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Argon, do you have anything to say to this O'Brien character? Poppy looks at the mic, several others surrounding it.

dialogues.speaker: POPPY
